Paracetamol.description: Paracetamol is commonly used to reduce fever and relieve mild to moderate pain. It is widely available and considered safe when taken as directed.
Paracetamol.who_should_take: Recommended for individuals with fever, headaches, muscle pain, or mild arthritis pain.
Paracetamol.who_should_avoid: Avoid if you have liver disease, alcohol dependency, or an allergy to acetaminophen.
Paracetamol.precautions: Do not exceed the recommended dosage. Overdose can cause severe liver damage.

Dextromethorphan.description: Dextromethorphan is a cough suppressant that helps reduce the urge to cough, making it useful for treating dry, non-productive coughs.
Dextromethorphan.who_should_take: Suitable for adults and children over 12 who have persistent dry coughs.
Dextromethorphan.who_should_avoid: Not recommended for children under 4, people with asthma, or those taking MAOI antidepressants.
Dextromethorphan.precautions: Avoid alcohol and other sedatives while taking this medicine, as it can cause drowsiness.

Antihistamine.description: Antihistamines are used to relieve allergy symptoms such as sneezing, itching, and runny nose. They are also used for cold symptoms and motion sickness.
Antihistamine.who_should_take: People with seasonal allergies, cold symptoms, or mild allergic reactions.
Antihistamine.who_should_avoid: Avoid if you have glaucoma, an enlarged prostate, or are taking sedatives.
Antihistamine.precautions: Some antihistamines cause drowsiness; avoid driving or operating machinery after taking them.

Ibuprofen.description: Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that reduces pain, inflammation, and fever.
Ibuprofen.who_should_take: Recommended for individuals with muscle pain, headaches, menstrual cramps, or mild arthritis pain.
Ibuprofen.who_should_avoid: Avoid if you have a history of stomach ulcers, kidney disease, or are allergic to NSAIDs.
Ibuprofen.precautions: Take with food to reduce stomach irritation. Long-term use can increase the risk of heart attack or stroke.
